How does the design argument prove the existence of God? The argument from design essentially holds that things that appear to be designed to us must be designed, and, since nature looks designed to some of us (which is not the case with me and many others), it must be designed. Personally, I find a distinction between human designs and what is found in nature, and note that a Samsung Smartwatch would stick out like a sore thumb sitting in the woods in a natural environment, unlike a naturally occurring thing, such as a tree or mushroom. The closest to the appearance of design that I can see in nature is certain biological life, but that order and complexity has been fully explained by evolutionary biology, in which order and complexity, as well as function, arises as the result of the non-random process of evolution. Scientists have not only observed evolution in controlled and uncontrolled conditions in the lab and field, the theory is supported by all the evidence, observations, predictions, experiments, and relevant facts, and is unanimously supported by the global scientific community. Evolution is classified as both a fact and a well-substantiated theory, and is as certain as the fact that the Earth is not flat. It is enough to disprove the argument from design, that the appearance of design in nature requires an intelligent designer. We’ve watched an unintelligent process produce new species, new ‘designs’, if you will. The problem with saying that anything with the impression of design must be designed, is that the God theists credit with design looks far more designed than anything else I can think of, and, unlike anything in nature, he is utterly perfect to boot, so he absolutely must be designed, if we follow theist apologist reasoning. If God can simply exist, looking so designed he is literally perfect, I see no reason why we, who are imperfect and far less orderly and complex, cannot exist without being designed. As it is, arguments don’t prove things. Proof is something that exists in mathematics, and we must otherwise rely on evidence and logic to get to the bottom of things. Arguments are not evidence. One can use an argument to reach a conclusion, but then the conclusion has to be supported directly by evidence. You cannot just leave it at the conclusion. There is more to it. So far, there is no evidence for the existence of God, or any superhuman intelligent designer, and humans have had thousands of years to cough it up. It’s about time we just move on, and hope that God, if he exists, will do what humans have failed to, which is to show that he exists.

It doesn't. Arguments don't prove anything. I can make you the most elegant, most flowery, most compelling argument for why there is a 10m tall statue of Woody Woodpecker somewhere on the surface of Titan, but until I can find the statue and show that it exists, I cannot prove that it's there. You'd just have to take my word. The design argument is not the most elegant, flowery or compelling argument for the existence of a god. It is, in fact, a silly argument that flies in the face of evidence and does not really prove the existence of any deities, but rather just suggests that there should (more on that little word in a moment) be some sort of “designer”, because the proponents of the argument cannot fathom how a complex system can arise from simpler processes. Now, about that “should” - there's a popular quote that you often see here on Quora: the universe is under no obligation to make sense to you. It doesn't matter how you think the world should work. It works however it works, and all we can do is observe the universe and deduce its workings based on what we find. There is no “should” - the universe is what it is. And for fuck's sake, either stop capitalizing the word “god” or specify which of the thousands of deities you are talking about.

It’s called “argument from design.” Teleology means that things have purpose, (also, order, harmony, intelligence, and design), proving a Supreme Mind or Intelligence. If you found a watch in the forest (the famous watchmaker argument) you’d suspect it was designed by an intelligent being and not just some accident or fluke of nature. This intelligent design of nature (ID) is see in signs of intelligence in all life forms in the form of DNA (the fingerprint or language of God). The so-called Anthropic Principle which shows earth as a privileged planet is another sign of intellgence, thus a Supreme Mind at work. In this vein, design must imply a Designer; as plans imply a Planner; art, an Artist; purpose a Purposer; order, and Orderer; and intelligence must imply a Mind at work. Teleology is an unwelcome word to Secularists who refuse to see design or purpose in nature but attribute it to “adaptation.” They fail to account for where this ability to adapt came from—God gave all creatures some adaptive abilities.
